kI1I_mbRwCyotUBuhf50RQ.text: This place is a must, worth going all the way north to get a crepe...people have a good reason to queue! Go for any of the savoury crepes...and then have a sweet one for dessert :)

XytzyI37UVoSxMjlVxp9Lw.text: Best creperie in Hampstead. I agree that it is really worth the wait. They use high quality ingredients and the combination is definely a winner!

XRjJIb4Pboys8iQzx9xd2Q.text: This is perhaps the best creperie in the world, the owner has the pancake hotplates specially made. My favorite crepe is Belgium chocolate, banana and Cointreau or Grand Marinier (not in menu) I have a blog post, here is the link: gourmettraveller88.com/2…

vaWZjbn_Tp3Ho9Hin4ofeQ.text: The first time I saw this little stand I could have easily failed to notice, but it was the queue that made me curious. What was going on? Just best crepes in town someone said, and even though I had no plans of eating anything sweet, I joined the queue.I was not disappointed. It really was so good. I am not so into crepes as they are often drowned with crease and also taste like it. But these ones had the perfect construction and were light and tasty. If only the queue were anything less than half an hour..

BWq3aquxeKfyBIUjLNFaQw.text: As much as I hate statements like this on the whole, I really do think that the crepes at this small but popular stall are as good as any you'll find in Paris (certainly better than many). Testament to this is the constant massive queue snaking away from it. Crepes are always made fresh so it'll take a while to get served but you will have had the pleasure and anticipation of watching it being made and seeing every ingredient with your own eyes. They are always nicely packed with goodies whether sweet or savoury and the chocolate ones are made with real chocolate of your choice. This is a great spot for a pre-pub stomach liner supper or a mid-shopping lunch, particularly in the summer when you can sit on a bench and eat it outside.

LIyuyv8JGSftmxEpRUtIcw.text: Join the masses and get in line for one of the most notorious places in London to get a crepe, or "pancake" as it is more commonly known. Lots of different toppings to choose from, and if only they didn't use quite such salty butter, they would be up there with the best pancakes in the world.

icVZ9EdG0yPIwguefn698Q.text: This is a little stall on the high street. it closes at 11pm and there are ques if you go after 10pm. there are sweet and savoury crepes with toppings such as chocolate, biscuits, fruits, honey, cinnamon, bacon, asparagus etc. everything is £3-5 and is served in a cone shaped cardboard box, napkin and fork. the crepes are delicious and is known by many as the best in London.

KLEuSs8BEU0VifZhp0y4Ww.text: This is a lovely little stand situated at the top of the hampstead high street serving both savoury and sweet crepes. The portions are pretty generous for the prices. There is a wide selection to choose from but the nutella and banana combo always seems to be what everyone is ordering. It is perfectly located just five minutes from the hampstead heath so that you can pick up some crepes and head to the park when the weather is fine. The great thing is that it is open late ( till 11) so you can even have a little bite there before heading out to town. The only negative thing is that the queue can somethimes take up to 20 minutes, so be prepared to wait!!! It is definetely worth it.

RcYgXBEctwS5PGF5jT17RA.text: My go-to place to satisfy my crepe cravings. I have been visiting La creperie for at least 10 years and do feel they have become a bit more doughy than they used to be. Oh well, I still keep coming back!These crepes make the long wait in the cold definitely worth it!

G2MqxBociO9Ny9ipDfHoyQ.text: This tiny stand in the centre of Hampstead usually has a huge queue of people, and for good reason. I've queued there many times, and was never disappointed. They make genuine French crepes, either sweet or savory, and everyone I've taken there has had the same reaction as me: I want more. Asparagus and cheese, ham and cheese, mushrooms and cheese, chocolate and banana, chocolate and creme; there are dozens of types, including choices of chocolate. You can get them wrapped to eat right away, or put in a take-away container. The price is right, the options are great, and the taste is out of this world. If only the queues weren't so long, I'd give it 5 stars (I can't always wait 30 minutes to be served).

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

ekd2xDlklgQ4OFxXmhlI3Q.text: Expect to wait a long time but it's totally worth it! The crepes are just gorgeous, made in front of you and by obvious professionals. You might as well grab a pint from the pub next door to sip while you wait. But these are really must-try crepes, I suggest you do it at least once. Just don't... eat anything beforehand!

s7qcCN9jnpk9Ni9U7YBYcw.text: I love crepes! If I had to be a food, I would be a crepe! (I really would) This is one of the best places in London to get a crepe.  Not too far from Hampstead station and fantastic in summer.There is only one reason why I gave it four stars.  I go here regularly (Remember I love crepes :P) and they have recently recruited a new crepe maker, and well it just wasn't very good :( it was too thick.  Don't let this put you off, I am sure he will get better :) this place is very authentic and I will of course go back.  There are a few benches but there really isn't many places to sit so not great in winter.  This is a great place in summer though. You need to go here if you like a good crepe :)

0XbR-MTjIt3-oS9SXyRfcQ.text: Expect to wait a long time but it's worth it.If you dont know Hampstead you might miss the little hut tucked away next to a pub but you will no doubt see an endless queue of people.The Crepes are superb with an extensive list of toppings to choose from both savoury and sweet.I went for milk chocolate and bananas priced at £4.50.I personally think there should be one on every corner of London.

emPixEDfdL_9jk0RUnnBHw.text: I used to work close by to this place a couple of years back and there were always  long queues, for this place, to my astonishment  when my friend and I dropped buy at  9 in the evening it was just us. I wondered why but read on, and you'll see why. I believe this place is extremely over rated but most importantly the staff are rude, exceptionally rude, I have never come across  people who work in  food stalls ( and they are many in London ), who don't take pride in the food they serve, where do i start ? . We  were looking to have something  sweet and savoury, so we could  both try  each other crêpesI ordered the Nutella  whilst  she went for the ham and cheese crêpe and both were disappointing all round . The ham and cheese crêpe   was not cooked properly and  had  processed ham ,  the guy  in the black shirt the rudest of them all ,   just threw in  the processed ham plus the  cheese and charged   a whopping £4.50,  at this point I was unsure even if should bother ordering my own crêpe having just witnessed that ,(A) the crêpe was not cooked, B) processed ham was used it literally looked like  it just came from Tesco No Frills Range  C) the  attitude of the French guy in the black top.   I have enclosed pictures, so be warned before you go there.  The nutella crêpe was soggy , but what made matters worse, was whilst the crêpe was cooking  the guy in the black shirt wiped his sweaty forehead with his hand  then proceed to finishing making the  crêpe, with the hand he had just used, disgusting or what. I know it is a small stall but general hygiene practice should be in place.   And it wasn't   as if he was the only one in the stall, there was another  guy and  he just stood there.  Whatever you do, DO NOT  go there, the food is not great at all, it no longer bewilders me,  that there were no queues when we went, it clearly evident  the food is terrible  and the customer service is equally as horrendous . You have been warned

PEbwv5d-eZYXwLwl6L8rcA.text: The crepes here are really yummy! Everytime I pass it, there is a queue - it is so popular! The only slightly annoying thing is that they have no seating and therefore you HAVE to get a takeaway. The solution: benches on the other side of road - not too bad. This is probably going to make me sound strange but the little cardboard cones they put their crepes in makes walking and eating very easy. I get so frustrated if I cannot eat my crepe properly because it is dribbling down my hand and into my jacket - sticky annoyance! They have all the regular choices but the lemon juice is from real lemons (and not a plastic bottle) and the nuts can be almonds or brazil nuts - yummy!

dB3ru3oF4C97EmlIYAQ58Q.text: Best you'll ever buy... people are ALWAYS queuing here day and night, sun or rain.

ZiVAjoT1sBHoqJLeO6KdiA.text: Used to pass this place everyday on my way home from the tube. The queue always intrigued me until one rainy day I myself decided to jump in for the fun. The crepe, while definitely good for london standard, is not so extraodianry as the long wait would seem to suggest. It surely isn't expensive and the slob of filling that they throw on may justify any lack of subtlety. But it's Hampsead and there's love for every walk of elegance.

3Eea6WDU83AzBCcedAXAew.text: yup, finally tried this famous creperie. usually i just see the queue and walk away, but this time we decided to stick it out since at least three of us wanted to try it. i got the spinach ham and garlic one and it was good yes. when i see the price is £4.80 i think it's probably okay. if my brain defaults and calculates $8 i feel sad. after 3 years in London, i tend not to convert anymore, but after a week bouncing from pounds, euros, and forints, my brain was converting currencies on its own.very tasty indeed but the amount of butter you see them use is actually sort of horrifying. also if you find it difficult to drink and walk at the same time like i do, there's almost no hope of trying to eat this crepe on the go.

CA06MXKpFRHLPG_agM4PsQ.text: This place is a good place to come if you enjoy the style of pancakes that they eat in France. I enjoyed mine but was just a little bit disappointed by the selection of fillings. It's a personal thing - all my favourites were notable by their absence.

0NTAfAfaBsxu41l_P3BNaA.text: I never post comment on-line but I decided to take the plunge after such a bad experience.I fully agree with Michael's comment below. These are not crepes at all!I grew up in Paris so I pretty much know how a crepe should taste like.A crepe shouldn't be fried. it shouldn't be overfilled.My crepe was fried with butter, overfilled with cheese and I ended up being sick the whole afternoon because of all the grease... But the worse part was the service. The two French girls cooking the crepes apparently think they are the only French-speaking in London because they kept mocking and bitching on the customers in French, in front of them... I could not believe my ears!As a conclusion: please do not go there, I am really chocked that such bad persons could be so successful with such a bad cuisine.

rYZyPx5TuGbs-Ip2aBM4eg.text: Everyone seems to know about this place and it's always busy. Great crepes with a selection of fillings, both savoury and sweet. You can't visit Hampstead and not try the crepes!

ZaEmJG0-y86xRnSZvJBuiQ.text: We waited 90 minutes to be served. NINETY MINUTES. The food was just okay, and the staff were surly and monosyllabic. If you really have a hankering for a stuffed pancake, you can get one for the same quality and price on Camden High Street. And you'll be served in five minutes.

W9GsMb_FkxtCg_EhCTrSeg.text: Food was really good, but had to wait longer than expected

K1hKQplOnw9m3wxoyJ_U5w.text: Some people will moan about the waitbut that's just part of it's charm! Renowned London over, this humble little crepe stall in the middle of gorgeous Hampstead is responsible for some of the most delicious crepes this side of The Seine. A perfect date destination, half the fun is snuggling up to your loved one or chatting with friends in the queue (sometimes quick, sometimes long)...before you indulge in sweet or savoury yumminesswhether it be pre-movie or after dinnerOne of my fave places in Londonit is worth the trek North for all you South Londoners!

ub4_qhFvw-baHog61CWz0A.text: I live locally and at least a little bit of the weight I've gained in the past year is due to the delicious crepes at Hampstead Creperie... I'd recommend the savoury crepes for dinner or lunch, and a walk in the Heath nearby to top it off!

BHFhiN7UTA3ZAUTpsaD3HA.text: This needs little description -- best creperie experience outside of the streets of Paris. A must go.

SNz6QovemXXHP52CZEL1ww.text: Who waits 45 minutes in line at a hot dog stand? I do, if the hot dog stand is actually La Creperie de Hampstead, vendor of the best crepes in all of Londontown. Amazing that this little creperie has done so well for so long. But the crepes are seriously good! Perfectly folded, perfectly crisp and soft in parts. Triple chocolate and bananas? Sign me up. Or really, for anything with Nutella in the name. The line moves as fast as they make the crepes, which is decently fast, but just take your time, come with a friend or eight, and y'all be patient while you wait for sweet sugary goodness. This place is in Let's Go London and some other guidebooks unfortunately, which probably adds to the queue, but Hampstead is still more or less off the beaten path for most tourists, so I think we can all still consider it a local find.

aC8LxRg_XtBORMvG9HCdYQ.text: My experience here was OK, but I've liked crepes better at stands in other cities (and in the kitchens of friends).  Annalise's review makes an important point: the quality of the fillings varies a lot.  My group got a crepe complete (ham, cheese, egg) that was very good, a spinach and garlic crepe that was fine, and a mushroom crepe that had what seemed to be unappetizing tinned mushrooms.  I would have given them four stars, three and a half stars, and one and a half stars, respectively.  They really do use too much butter on the pan; some butter adds crispiness and richness, of course, but in this quantity the excess just makes everything heavy.  Still, the best options on the menu will be a good choice for a casual, relatively inexpensive meal in Hampstead.

1czEH8ADq_7BLMW5iCo38w.text: I am a little surprised by all the glowing recommendations.'La Creperie de Hampstead' is certainly popular, but is neither an ideal way to savour a pancake (outside) or for that matter quality worthy of 5 or even 4 stars.I tend to go for the sweet options like Banana, chocolate & cream as I find the savoury versions just to "sloppy" for my standards.Part of the charm must be people walking down  Hampstead High Street and seeing a queue and thinking: "Whats this?" "OK, I will have a crepe too".The thing being there are NOT many places to have a French style pancake in London, so if you fancy a different snack it is a nice change.Personally, if I am in the mood I would rather head to Chelsea, Kensington OR Bloomsbury which all have a branch of pancake chain 'My Old Dutch'. They are superior in taste, quality and you can eat inside!This kiosk is cheaper, though and I do recommend trying them at least once if you are in the area and in the mood. Finding a suitable place to eat one may be your biggest challenge.

iA1wVA4KG6cJP7HbKUwzog.text: What a fantastic place. Yes it's touristy and without a doubt there will be a good ten minute queue...but worth the wait.Although I'm normally a nutella girl myself, it's ALL about the banana butterscotch cream dream. I'm salivating just thinking about it as I type this review! Some of the fillings are out of a can / jar, but don't let this put you off. They taste fabulous.

UgDRA6B3TdnTv5uO3tLtgg.text: Sweet jesus, crepes that are worth the plane ride to get here.  Tucked into a corner of Hampstead, La Creperie, is simply a stand manned by 2 French guys, but the magical crepes are delicious.Regardless of whether you think yourself above this seemingly simple French delight, get a crepe.  I did dark chocolate and banana (3 types of choco to choose from, dark, milk, and white, all godly)--and within 3 steps of the cart I looked like a child enjoying chocolate for the first time as my entire face was covered in its chocolately goodness and dear lord was it good.  Nath enjoyed the crepe suzette and was thrilled with his somewhat cleaner experience.Nice selection of savories as well.  Like Nike said, just do it.

SI0AMJiqsDtZhRJDpAQWog.text: I'm going to be working next to here again, I'm going to be working here again, cha cha cha. It made me fat last time and it will do again, Asparagus crepe's FOR THE WIN!

LqiVGrcaYla5ZWE4Qj7IUg.text: Save yourself a trip across the Channel. The crepes at this cute little kiosk in Hampstead Heath are the real deal. In fact, if you consider crepes in France as the real deal, then these Hampstead ones might be even more real and a better deal. Sweet fillings are good, of course, but I always go for the savoury: ham, cheese, mushrooms, garlic... I think it's because the first crepe I ever had (while in Paris on an exchange trip) was savoury.With your crepe(s) in hand, take a stroll around the area. It's really cute: cozy cafes and pastry shops with enticing window displays. From the tube station, walk down the hill, and you'll see the stand. If you don't see it, it's because it's obscured by the long queue of hungry tourists and regulars. You'll see why.

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

Ps_rjdIEWWxN3_oNZY3ERg.text: Ilike this small stands. There are manyselections of sweet and salty pancakeshere in Old Dutch house. This store sells the finest pancakes in town that youcan experience. I ordered a milk chocolate and banana, and I'm very pleased. It is really lovelyand very good. The environment is cool and very welcoming, the system is good,and the customer service personnel are friendly and very funny. Good place tograb some foods. I recommend both dinner & breakfasts to get foods here.

HigtsJsE9B_hi44euC4Vtw.text: So, so, so good. If you ate here every day, you would have a heart attack for sure. They slice butter *lengthwise* for the grill... Which, of course, results in delicious crepes with just the right amount of crispiness.The service is rather brusque, but they're churning out crepes as fast as they can for the unending line of customers.Finally, I would advise against any of the savory crepes that have cream rather than cheese... The mess you're liable to make is not worth the calories saved via said mess.

VT5uc-HcK1pIX6iH8LI4zw.text: The Creperie de Hampstead is an absolute MUST.  If you are a tourist, a visit to the Creperie should be on your list. And if you are a local and you haven't been, go, go, go now!Savory? Sweet????NomNomNomzzzzJust to warn you, the que can get rather long. But there's a reason why.  It's well worth the wait!

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

TYHL9bvcUf-D6Ot8I2EB-A.text: Felt like I got to try an absolute hampstead gem today! I had the banana maple cream dream which is apparently there most popular crepe. I didn't even look at the other items..I knew that was the perfect one for me. I love finding little gems like this..its been open for 32 years and today I signed the petition to keep it open. Whoever is trying to close this place is clearly unwell in the head.

WxQhGG0vcfgX-WaL3LhQGw.text: So, this is my first Yelp review in almost two years. I don't even live in London anymore. La Creperie de Hampstead is kind of a really big deal.I lived in Hampstead when I studied abroad at King's College London and King William IV quickly became one of my favorite local pubs. I noticed the long queues for this little crepe stand from the pub windows one day and knew I HAD to eat here.Even though I ADORE Nutella on just about everything (I have been caught, on more than one occasion, eating straight out of Costco-sized jars... without a spoon), I definitely recommend the savory crepes over the sweet ones here - there is something truly magical about the giant pats of butter and generous heapings of cheese that go into every savory crepe that you just have to experience for yourself! I am not ashamed to admit that I still dream about Hampstead crepes sometimes. I loved how the crepes were served in paper cones with tiny forks, and my favorite spot to eat them was on the metal bench in front of Gail's. The bench faced Hampstead Station was the perfect spot for people-watching on Hampstead High Street. Learning how to unravel the perforated paper cones with expertise took a little practice, but I was a pro by the time I had to say goodbye to London and return to California.Honestly, these street crepes were WAY better than any crepe I tried in any Francophone destination I visited while I was abroad - crepes in Paris, Lyon, or Brussels simply could not compare to the perfectly crispy crepe cones coming from this little North London gem.Note: their mushrooms come from a can. People can be very weird about mushrooms (for instance, I personally cannot eat raw mushrooms because the texture reminds me of fleshy human ear lobes and really freaks me out!), so do not order mushrooms as a topping if you cannot handle the canned fungus!

ICylJkpptZFMibcamlGt9w.text: This crepe cart, staffed by French gals last time I checked, serves up some tasty fare.  Hampstead, too, is lovely, so to nibble on a nice crepe while strolling about in an attractive area is a sure-fire hit.The only bummer nowadays would be that everyone and their mother visit La Creperie de Hampstead.  The wait for food could be off-putting. :(

k_TTENx7FdagPvqVsmArXQ.text: Honestly one of the best crepes ever!The french transplants that run this place do a perfect job of making that cheesy, garlicy, mushroomy perfection inside a equally perfected crispy crepe!The quality of the ingredients really sets it off...obviously the most important...the CHEESE. Its a good swiss cooked with garlic butter! Need I say anymore.Lets continue with the crepe itself, as the batter is the other great half. The crepe is perfectly crispy but holds its form! If you're ever in the area....grab a bite from here.Also if you're feeling something sweet, you should work up to those nutella crepes that taste oh so good!Then talk a little with the workers, who continually speak in french with their co-workers, some parisians, some senegalese. Use your french and they'll continue the conversation with you!

oH4ZcCeXkO_Mvwgyw-C9KQ.text: I have one word. BUTTERRRRROOOMMMGGGDDRROOOOLLLLThe best crepe I have ever had. Super buttery and tasty and messy and perfect.I always get the ham with garlic mushrooms and cheese. so good. Just not good date food, unless he's eating something similarly garlic-y...then it cancels itself out. right? god I hope so cause Im going to eat it anyway.There are various benches and bus stops around the area that you can sit on if its not too busy. But its easily eaten while walking around this pleasant neighborhood. watch out towards the end though it gets drippy.It's about £4.50 I think. Can't remember but would gladly pay more for this delight. I know! Just for you I will go back this weekend and find out that price for sure. See how I take care of you yelpers?! So loving.

uTetkgTEx1wQ4CJaFMoOdQ.text: I'm really surprised by all the positive reviews for this admittedly cute, French-speaker manned crepe station.  It was fun to hear them bitch about their lives, unknowing or uncaring that French speakers like myself could eavesdrop.I've had crepes aplenty, most in Montreal where crepes are easy to find and quite good.  The defining quality of the crepe, to me, is a delicateness of texture and a harmony of complimentary subtle flavours inside.  I wasn't too enthused, then, when I watched her slam a giant stick of butter on the hot plate that my crepe entirely absorbed, presumably to crisp it enough to hold it's shape.. and then it sat there turning into cardboard for way too long.  Then, my cheese and spinach filling were much too abundant, creating a heavy mass of goop whose texture almost entirely took over the experience.  Never mind that my very first bite, the lip of the crackled crepe alone, proved to be much too salty and of course, greasy from the butter overdose.If you want some lead in your stomach (savory) or a giant sugar buzz (sweet) to fuel your wanderings, fine, go for it.  But if you want a proper experience, find a place where the crepe is light, and the filling carefully considered in proportion. Not this place.

Tm-APNExS9zAGa34z7h0LA.text: The best crepes in London - and maybe France!  La Creperie is a traditional Parisian street creperie located in Hampstead Village.  It has been in Hampstead Village for over 30 years!  And, if you don't trust my review, just walk by.  There is always a line - which means it is in high demand!It's a treat for dessert (I recommend the milk chocolate and banana, or dark hazlenut creme).  The ham and Gruyère cheese, which is my favourite, is also great for a quick lunch.  Expect to pay about £3.50 - £4.00.

Bk1ZUlFenO26F7aAOwhDSw.text: OMG my first real French crepe.It is quite different from the crepes I got in Harajuku, Tokyo but nonetheless delicious. A bit heavy, I saw the guy smack a big slice of butter onto the pan thingy. I had the sweet crepes, hazlenut dark choco cream and wow, I haven't ate this much chocolate in one sitting, they actually use real pieces of chocolate and it starts to melt slowly once cooked. MMMmm is all i gotta say. Also the best is to order one and take a picnic at the beautiful hampstead heath. I was in heaven, (luckily it was a sunny day)

VvnOGJk1-tiD2ErSJEk5kg.text: It seems to be a bit of an unwritten rule of catering that if you are just going to sell one thing - one particular item of food you are allowed to operate from something that could feasible be fitted to the back of a horse and dragged off. Think about it, burgers, hot dog stands...creperies. They're always small, mobile little joints and can be moved around. They just never are. This one's got a permanent address and everything. And to be honest the crepes at this place are so good it's tempting. This is a Hampstead institution really, it's been here since the 80's and is known for it's queues on busy days. The deal is you can either have sweet or savoury and within that there are loads of different choices, classics like suzette, ham and cheese, mushrooms, chocolate, banana, nuts, really varied. Of course everything's made right in front of you are and 1 should set you back between about £2 and £5.

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

pMhCIN_3-9e4b_gvoppYqg.text: Seriously the best meal I had in London! Extremely delicious, filling and affordable!

fNSrjJX0btRvt82gJjD6QA.text: This place is not hype. It's the real thing. If you are in London, this is where you need to be at some point. The line gets long, the wait is worth it. Both. Sweet and savory crepes are good. I suggest getting both, one for dinner and one for dessert. Yes.

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

xrBdspiLqYbYMRocqCHmeA.text: La Creperie de Hampstead, is a small little Parisian kiosk that on many a night, you may find a queue of people making you wait for up to 45 minutes, but this wait is worth it,  for what may be one of the greatest pancakes experiences you have ever had. The smell is awesome, and the wait builds anticipation for that first bite. As you get closer, you can choose what kind of pancake you want, savoury or sweet. If I fancy a savoury, I will definitely be getting a sweet along with it, as it's a pancake for crying out loud! It's a desert, I always get the sweet. Once you put your order in, you have the pleasure of watching two pancake making maestros, passionately whoop up your treat. It is actually quite educational as I tend to have my eyes glued to what they are doing. I have been going here for years, and each time is as good as the next. For those of you that have been here before, well I am sure that you share my passion. For those of you who have yet to experience the Crepes of Hampstead, well, the next time you are on the Northern line Tube, get off at Hampstead, at the exit turn left, and you will see it across the road, it is a minutes walk away. During the day you may get lucky and not find a queue.It is set in Hampstead, where you can take your pancake for a lovely walk, and stop off at the nearby café's and have a coffee to wash it down. My personal rating, 11 out of 10.

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

FcHcB9bH5Vof0x_XZQgUWg.text: I went to Paris searching for good crepes and none is better than this place in London!The crepes were amazing. I tried the savory chicken mushroom. It was heaven in my mouth. My friends told me there was a famous London rapper on the side eating it too with his entourage. Guess this place is the spot. No wonder there was a long line to get these delicious crepes. If I'm ever in town, I'll be back at this place to start my trip and again to end my trip. What a good food experience.

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Mushroom Savory. So good!
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

GZ0x1yl-87aklcCp08kPzw.text: Get to the Chase:Pros:1) More than 30 years in business2) Hands down the best crepes I've ever had3) Every time I visit London with the family, we make it a must to visit here4) I love their nutella and banana crepe, and their savory crepes are equally as good (try the spinach, cheese, and mushroom)Cons:1) Tends to be a long line which could easily take up to 20 min or more waiting outside2) Not open every day (only Fri, Sat and Sun)...but that could be just recently

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

lat5VOk-O0sMW7xvAj65Cw.text: Amazing crepes! Lucky we only had 2 people in front of us!The boys were super quick in making the crepes anyway so it was fine.  Had the garlic mushroom, cheese and ham. They got me at 'garlic'... It was delicious! Crispy on the outside, garlicky goodness on the inside! Instantly makes you want another one!

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Garlic mushrooms, ham and cheese!

s3hQEwdTsKKmLdpC3xWVRw.text: This Hampstead institution is well worth a trip. When the crepes are buttery crisp and filled with delicious savoury fillings - it's about as good as street food can get. I always get the crepe complete, which is ham, egg and cheese, though I've had it without ham recently as to be honest the ham is cheap supermarket bland stuff, which I think detracts from the overall flavour (my bf feels the same about the asparagus). But stick to basics and it's a taste sensation. If you come at a busy time, waits are often about half an hour, and there's obviously nowhere to sit, though plenty of benches around (or green spaces if you can manage not to eat it immediately). So I wouldn't do it all the time but it's a good treat and definitely worth it if you're new to the area.

kHJwfjVhVFWRizOC8UTjPw.text: Do I really have to explain? ;) the Creperie on Hampstead is an organic part of our walks now, it's the zenith. I used to eat only their sweet crepes, but once I tried a ham/cheese mushroom one, I am now a big fan of their savoury crepes. Hmmm, it's been a good couple of months since we've last bin there actually... ;)

F-qPTBZU2CV2wl8Sq5flBQ.text: Love this little stand. Went in January around New Years & had a wonderful banana & Nutella crepe. The first time I had a crepe from this stand was back in 2005 & so happy it's still rolling out delicious crepes. The line was a bit long, but honestly it was maybe a 10 min. wait. I'm not much of a savory type of gal, I stick with the classic and it was delicious like I remembered it. I came all the way from Richmond Park to enjoy my crepe. This is a must for Hampstead Heath & crepe fans!

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Final touch of chocolate bliss
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. View from across the street
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Menu

lEyNff5JWb_-JIeU11v4gg.text: Hands down one of my favourite meals ever! I have been here several times whilst visiting London from the USA. My all time favourite crepe is the dark chocolate with hazelnut. All fresh ingredients and delicious!! Just FYI they are closed Monday and Tuesday. Go go go!!

Pt6bsSK3kprwitixDVGz2w.text: La Creperie has been in Hampstead for as long as I can remember, and I have always wondered why there are no permanent place, but I guess that is all part of the experience. Being stood in a queue, often a bit chilly outside, jealous of those just about to tuck into the sweet and savoury crepes, waiting patiently alongside mothers equipped with wet wipes and tissues for the messy, sticky delights to be devoured... If you have a sweet tooth like me, you can get white, milk, dark chocolate, with nuts, or maple and bananas, butterscotch cream or the class lemon and sugar. You can even be naughty and have some rum! If you are to have an indulgent snack/lunch you could go for mushrooms, garlic and cheese, even the likes of asparagus, although that's not my fave veg in the world... There are plenty of variations and that is why I am back there a few times a month !..oh yeah, you will need some extra tissues ! Enjoy !

XzEFQ2SHy6QWKYa5bEQc3g.text: Worth the hype and the wait!The sweet crepe with banana and dark Belgian chocolate was divine.It's a small road side stand, so be prepared to queue and bring cash.

GJ82I-_QRh3xd8Bs6kw6Tg.text: This place is an institution, and rightly so. They don't just import their ingredients from the mainland; they import their workers from there, too.These guys know how to make a crepe, and if you're in the area, it'd be criminal not to try it (the queue only shows you how many people agree with me).

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Like a beacon in the summer night.

sQV5NwhyRwt9ra2wTLBN2Q.text: The smell from the hut alone will draw you in!!This place is a must if you like good quality chocolate oozing from your crepes!!!I've seen previous reviews regarding how long the line is but when I went there was only 3 people in front of me so did not wait more than 5 minutes.

dKlrnaoGbnc1fdTE8JfTfg.text: A must visit in Hampstead.  The crepe stand is a tradition hereI love any of the savory ones with asparagus.  The service is quick and its very reasonable for one of the most expensive areas in London. All you need to do is find a place to eat it.

9qHQt7HhCs9HNLql4Yj0Hg.text: Super yummy crepes with a super long line! Delicious menu and love the neighborhood this stand is in. We sat on a park and people watched away. I loved the classic Nutella and the maple cream with bananas. Amazing!

4XJrt4Y3LI368UvYbb21mw.text: I was really excited to visit this place after seeing all the great reviews .. hoping that the crepes I ate in paris may be similar to these. I was hugely disappointed and I'm really trying to figure out how this shack has so many high ratings. There was no queue when I went and yet the crepes were rushed and soggy rather than crispy. I only had a simple Nutella filling and with the less than generous spread the crepe was falling apart. On top of this the two servers were rude, didn't say hello in return, were busy speaking in french to each other the whole time, asked us to repeat orders ect. I don't expect a song and dance in every place I go to eat, but basic manners would be nice. I wouldn't go to Hampstead just for these crepes and even if I was shopping on the high street I still wouldn't eat these.

s3DTGTXsx0_aE29YKnU2ww.text: Worth every minute of waiting in the (extremely) long queue. The praline milk chocolate is heavenly. Recommended with Banana and hazelnut.

CzZZ84CuNamM2wgX_8uKhw.text: I really want to give this place more stars but I really think I just ended up picking the bad filling for my crepe.The crepe itself was delicious, light and fluffy, and a definite rival to any crepe in Paris. Unfortunately, I picked the crepe aux pommes and instead of a fresh apple filling I received apple sauce out of a jar. I spent the entire time just eyeing my friends crepe which was filled with a delicious hazelnut filling.

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

j64Xmyptc-bTQPdJAWgkDA.text: Long queue but worth the wait.  It is a very tiny, outdoor crepeie, no where to sit but don't let that put you off.  It has a great number of options, all look delicious and quite filling.  The Belgian chocolate with banana is real yummy is looking for a sweet option and the ham, cheese and egg one was also delicious.  It is also amazing to see the crepes being made!Definitely a must visit!

bZeCqdGOrAzb30bqKcX7yA.text: Okay kind of over-hyped but I still love it. A legend in Hampstead, this crepe joint really delivers! I got a sweet crepe for dessert after dinner at Côte. My crepe included hazelnuts, bananas, white chocolate, and milk chocolate. The queue (line) here can be massive so be prepared to wait. However, it's so worth it! Even if you're not a big crepe fan, you have to try this local favorite and landmark at least once when visiting Hampstead. I would love to try the savory crepes as well. I heard from a local that the ham and cheese crepe is divine and incredibly popular. I thought the employees could have been more helpful when we were asking questions and could have smiled a bit more, but whatevs. Can't wait to come back!

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. My crepe with the business in the background.
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Voila!

siJldbl-GxoSDeNL82U8zA.text: Unlike the various establishments in hipster-populated areas, this street stall actually deserves the queue it attracts. Quality ingredients, service with a smile and probably London's best crepes make this place worth a visit even if it's raining!It's a better proposition than quite a few other places in Hampstead even if there's nowhere to sit :)

tRwZ1Hp1sSRgH17qww4BvA.text: This stall looks like a Hampstead institution.  We got there at 9:30pm on a Thursday night and there was a lengthy queue of hungry people buzzing with anticipation.  I could smell the crepes while I was waiting in line and it just made me more hungry!  While one of us held our place in line, my wife and I took turns checking the menu up the front to finalise our choices.I definitely could have had two or three of them.  Common sense took charge and I just got a savoury one with a filling of tarragon, cheese, mushroom and ham.  My wife got a similar one, but with garlic.  We also got a sweet one filled with milk belgian chocolate, to share for after.  They were delicious.  The cheese was stretchy, the mushrooms juicy and the crepe was strong enough to hold it all together.  You had to be careful with the sweet one though - if you weren't concentrating, then you might get some melted chocolate on your clothes!The lady in charge of the crepes is direct and to the point, asking the customer questions (to clarify the order) and letting them know when their answers were not useful!  Yet, it didn't feel rude at all.  It actually contributed to the charm of the place.Whenever I find myself roughly in the area, I would make a visit there for a crepe.  Sure thing!

hyO9a-l3I6NUE1YJ3c3ZHA.text: Cool crepe spot right off Hampstead Station. First time. I tried the banana crepe with chocolate. I needed some salt for taste bugt other than that it was amazing.

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

alym7ZGtocBlUeNyou78lA.text: Had a ratatouille crêpe and it was AMAZING. I've never had anything like it. Such a good combo of two French classics. The cheese was really savory and the crepe was perfectly light and scrumptious.

Y3oYoT8uI_yDt9hRSPmxcA.text: My Go-To. 'nough said.You'll probably have to be patient as a row of at least 15 to 20 people is certainly no exception ...but with good reason and well worth the wait.My fav's? Crêpe ratatouille and crêpe complet

lhxJ0cV75kwMZzw9oBpUgA.text: I was wondering what all the hope was about this place so I tried!WoW!! This is a must if you are in hampstead! I can't take my kids because the  thing but I have been there a few times.

nB0j5oeEXImpGXRhscJ7ag.text: I claim that I don't have a sweet tooth.I claim that I dislike anything in the 'pancake' family (this includes crepes).And yet, and yet: I MOWED MY WAY THROUGH MY PORTION OF A CREPE LIKE THERE WAS NO TOMORROW.We opted for the "classic" chocolate and chopped hazelnut option, with Belgian milk chocolate. The crepe itself was perfectly cooked; both tender and with a crispy edge. The salted butter added just the slighted hint of saltiness to counter the sweetness of the chocolate. The nuts brought the perfect textural component. Subtle details, but so important. I'm really keen to return for a savoury option: a range of mushroom, spinach, artichoke and asparagus alternatives, for instance. I have my eye on the crepe 'complet' which is ham shoulder, cheese, and an egg all wrapped up. As the menu says: the French riff on the full English breakfast! OUI, OUI.See a queue in Hampstead? It's probably for crepes, so...get in line!Yelp note: they occasionally do buckwheat crepes as well (but were out when I went).

AK1RmAZz6clHnpH1cX0Wsw.text: Came here on a rainy Saturday at about 3pm and there was no line, hooray! We were greeted with a very unhappy woman who looked like she did not want to be serving us. No hello, nothing. We ordered 2 savoury crepes and 1 sweet crepe, but the woman said nothing back - just started to make our crepes. I asked for all of our crepes to be wrapped up as it was raining and we were going to eat them back at the house, and I received a stern stare back without any words to acknowledge what I just asked. I am giving three stars because there was a lot of filling in the crepes and they tasted good, but not the best I've had either.  Cost £16 for all three and in the chocolate and banana crepe they used real chocolate chips and banana which tasted good.  The service really puts a downer on the whole business. No excuse for poor communication and unfriendly service.

7LnFZZ_XV5F9R5J8-cDeFA.text: My family and I stopped here on a Thursday around 1 pm (during Christmas term break, no less), and there was no queue. Service was fast--about 5 minutes for our three savory crepes. We tried the garlic mushroom, ham and cheese; garlic asparagus, ham, and cheese; and plain ham and cheese. All were delicious, warm, and flavorful. It was good, but I would not say it was amazing--I can't imagine waiting in a queue longer than 10 minutes for these! The flavors were simple and tasty, but not inventive or masterful, as I've found in some of my favorite London street food. I wish there were a bit more savory options--perhaps another type of meat besides ham, or some more savory sauces? I would stop again if I were walking around in Hampstead and the queue wasn't too long.

2k1slWFa2ZbyWF3jAiabdw.text: One of London's gems. A simple lemon and sugar crepe is all you need and you will be salivating. You walk up and are hesitant because of the size of the queue but make sure you wait - this is the best crepe I have ever had. I recommend La Creperie de Hampstead to anyone coming to London. Follow this by a walk through Hampstead Heath and you have had the best day.

NA1GR3XUw3UMFVT1p7n0ww.text: A Hampstead institution, I hope they never close!Years... years I have been coming here, and it's always been delightful. Ham cheese and a little bit of garlic mushrooms is my galette of choice here, always quickly made, always fresh, always hot and tasty. If there is a craving from my sweet tooth, some nutella and chopped nuts is the way to go.Stand in line, don't complain and you'll soon have it in your hands. These guys need to spend time to properly make your crepes, but they are efficient.They only have 2 crepe stations though, and it can take a little time if you have a group, generally the crepe is made on the first and then moved to the second for the filling.

XiXEDjHkgIc_1vlx1D8l1A.text: Just fantastic!I moved to this area 2 months ago and have been walking up and down the high street passing by the big queues that are outside this place....I just thought it was a touristy place and never wanted to go....One day on a rainy day I decided to go with my fiancee as we had tried everywhere else....We had the hazlenut chocolate crepe and as we bit into it while walking home we stopped, looked at each other and we said "Oh my god" "Yum"!... it was one of the most delicious crepes I have had...the crepe itself was soft and buttery and the filling was crunchy and smooth...That was the point when I thought "I love being a local in this area"...If you come to Hampstead, its a must...

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Opening times

51wA6jgRh8v4ojt1TBhzIQ.text: So the question here is do you want to have a PARTY in your mouth? ! If so, for all those visiting north London, or going to Hampstead Heath, take a minute to join the line outside this tiny stall that offers only the best pancakes in all of London.  Yes I said it, all of London. You have the option to chose savoury or sweet, I always go sweet because the pancake itself has this salty zingy flavour, and the perfect combination of sweet and salty explodes in your mouth once you try it. You can also ask them to combine the different chocolate flavours for an additional 50p or so, so you needn't do plain belgian chocolate alone, you can combine it with a bit of nutella or something else on the side depending on what you are in the mood for.

yVw1Qsphy8J_nKhtYYFB0Q.text: London's best crepe . No doubt!I have cheese ham and mushroom A generous amount of cheese, the crepe was cripsy and buttery. Lovely! Worth my 40 mins queue on a sunday afternoon

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

9dy8vh3CkZZP-_n350Gpog.text: Little stall in Hampstead that always has a queue but well worth the wait. I usually have a very sweet tooth and go for the dessert over starter 99% of the time, but at this place the savoury options won me over. I had a spinach, garlic, cheese and cream crepe, the crepe itself was really tasty and crisp yet fluffy. As a lover of all things spinachy or garlicky this crepe was perfect. The service is quite blunt, but when you see they are making 4 crepes simultaneously you understand why! Give this place a visit and you really won't regret it!

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

cUZkDK0M_qc-C64THjxCaw.text: The wait is massive...so prepare to wait. Also,  don't judge a book but it's cover.  This place doesn't look like much but the crepes are very very yummy. The crepes are big and decently priced. We tried the mushrooms garlic ham, the crepe complete (egg, ham, cheese)  and the Belgian chocolate with banana.  they were all delicious!  the Belgian chocolate was amazing.  it wasn't a syrup it was actually chocolate chips you would use to make fancy hot chocolate. I highly recommend it.  the staff is really nice and polite and they move fast!  the total amount for 3 crepes was 16£.

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom

p2r6eEX3rJchme-bh2slkA.text: Proper crêpe. I haven't had a better crêpe outside of France. I usually get the crêpe complète which contains cheese, ham and egg. The pancakes are cooked expertly on hot plates before they fold all the ingredients into a tasty wedge you take away and guzzle down. The crêperistas are fundamentally French; which means they know what they're doing and can be authentically rude. This is a good thing, if they are being friendly or polite it means the quality of crêpe suffers.I can only complain about the lack of galettes, and the size of the queue sometimes, which is just not acceptable when you need your hit of crêpe to sooth the withdrawal symptoms.Crêpes are generally less than £4 and they only take cash.

OgWw1nZFgCHmTEilBSM-tg.text: This is one of the little gems of Hampstead that has been around for years and is in every Official visit Hampstead Tour Books (I have 3 for London and all mention this place).Tucked down a side street near the King William IV pub is a little portable crepe cafe. You know when it's open as there is always a long queue of people waiting for their crepe. They do both savory and sweet. It's open Friday, Sat & Sunday.

iwSxn5YyZ40mModWGyBZEA.text: If you visit Hampstead and don't have a crepe from here then you haven't really been to Hampstead...simple! This place is a local institution, as evidenced by the local outrage when the pub tried to evict them. The queue is always long so if you do ever spot a short one jump at the chance. At weekends it can go around the corner, but it is definitely worth the wait. I always swear I'm trying a new one but I always end up with banana & milk chocolate. Yum!More recent claim to fame was a visit from Ashton & Mila when they were filming here :)

cakDbxqa3xeBXQniagr-HQ.text: LOVE!!! :) This is a tiny crepe kiosk that stays open till late, rain or shine, and is always busy because it is SO GOOD. I went there at 11pm on a dark weeknight, in the pouring rain, and there was still a long line for a crepe haha. I understand the devotion though, because this is a crepe institution, with it's delightful French staff who certainly know what they're doing.I have tried the savory crepe, which was decent, but my heart belongs to the chocolatey goodness of their dessert crepes. I can't even choose which is best, they have all been good. The yummy nutella, belgian dark, milk and white chocolate, bananas, hazelnuts, butterscotch, every combination I've tried has been delicious! Which reminds me, I need to go back, I haven't tried the white with milk chocolate combination yet....:)

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Love the packaging. Almost as good as what's inside!

2KVzTK9QNuBRRLY27WiX8g.text: Love it!  This is definitely the best place for a pancake in London!  The variety is amazing and the staff is always friendly.Only bad bit is, they are very popular when the weather is good...  The wait time can be more than 30 min!

QxG37jZBcWgMc_o3AStltQ.text: This little creperie stand is a perfect way to end the day at Hampstead Heath. The galettes are very delicious! It makes you feel as if you are in Paris. It's reasonably priced as well. All of my friends thought the crepes were delicious. There was a little bit of a queue, but definitely worth any wait!

photos.caption: Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Creperie de Hampstead - London, United Kingdom. Slimmers galette
